STEWART & WOOTTON
KISSES & KISSING.

A MORAL VIEW OF THE SUBJECT.

There seems to be nothing that can make people more happy than kissing. It is a natural instinct, and one that cannot be denied. The act of kissing is a sign of affection and love, and it is a way of expressing these feelings in a physical manner.

The act of kissing is not just limited to humans. Many animals also engage in kissing behavior. For example, dogs often lick each other's faces as a sign of affection. This behavior is similar to human kissing, where the lips are used to convey love and affection.

In conclusion, kissing is a natural and healthy way of expressing love and affection. It is a sign of connection and intimacy between two people.

SPINK & MAVETY, PROPRIETORS.

RIVER STREET, PRINCE ALBERT
ITEMS OF INTEREST.

An earthquake was felt at Athens recently.

Miss Ada J. Jackson, Danish lady, is dead.

The report of the death of Carway is confirmed.

Loughborough, the poet, left a property valued at $300,000.

A state of siege has been imposed on Niloos, Nepalese capital, for fear of a famine. Disgusted with the Khalsa, they have left all the churches lately.

A vessel lying at Craney Island, Va., has several cases of yellow fever aboard.

The Alamo Club, which had been closed for six months, arrived at Glasgow on July 25th.

The Municipal Council of Paris rejected the proposal to pay a loss of $200,000.

The news of Carway's death has produced a profound sensation throughout London.

King George IV visited the Crimea, where he died on the 26th of June.

At Kingston on the 25th July the transportation of the Nile P. W. O. took place.

Seven women and children were drowned by the upsetting of a boat in the river.

The French government proposes to use 50,000 francs to cover the cost of a similar misfortune in France.

It is reported that Mr. Vaughan has resigned that his husband is suffering from the effects of poison.

Fourteen persons have been committed to the Magistrate for complicity in the murder of Mrs. Smythe.

At Belleville, recently, Alex. Arbuthnot, owner of the "Belleville" on Trenton, was found dead in his room.

At Kingston one of Barrow's thieves put his pistol through his cage and killed W. Smith, who was sitting in the cage.

At Churchill, in Russia, several cases of cholera are reported, and great efforts are being made to prevent its spreading.

Another death of an aged man and woman occurred in the hospital in the Kingston jail—the fifth in two months.

The county as seen from the Nelson tower is said to be the most beautiful in the county of glens and valleys.

The opening of the International Electrical Exhibition has been announced.

Antiques will be sold at public auction.

It is understood that the late Henry Kendall makes a bequest of $10,000 to the public library of Providence.

The faculty of the new Woman's Medical College at Kingston have been sworn in.

The opening will take place in October.

The heavy rain which have prevailed in England during the past few days continues seriously to interfere with the harvest.

Cholera has spread to Russia, where a few cases are reported. The existence of the disease is said to be confirmed at London Bridge.

The suppression of the Tract Society by the Government brought into the possession of the authorities the press for some time.

The death of the Tract Society's leader, Mr. B. L., a three-year-old son of Mr. B. L., while playing with his mother in the attic, set fire to his clothes, and was burned to death.

The English government has withdrawn the agreement with M. de Lesseps concerning the Suez Canal.

The death of the Duchess of Kent was announced on July 27th, and she died after a short illness.

Mr. Macphail, prominent Presbyterian, resignation of any war declared repugnant, and the utilization of all parties is desirable.

On the 25th June, on the Wallachian border near Bessarabia, a freight train collided with a military train, killing 20 soldiers.

There was some agitation in financial circles at Montreal on the 25th June, when a report was received that the bank of the consolidated loan was about to warn exposure of the shareholders of the company.

J. L. JOHNSON & CO.
Have removed to their new building four doors west of the old stand.
N.B.-We claim to have the best assortment of Seed and Heavy Hardware in Prince Albert.
Prices Guaranteed Satisfactory.

REMOVED.
SHANNON & McLEOD have removed into their new store, one door west of their old stand, and are now prepared to give to the people of Prince Albert a quality of Boots and Shoes never before offered in this town.

The entire stock has been personally selected, and none but first-class material purchased. We keep no shoddy goods, and sell at prices that cannot be competed with. Our motto is small profits and splendid satisfaction.

Ordered work done in first-class style. Repairs promptly attended to. We intend keeping up our reputation for doing first-class work. Always on hand a good supply of leather, shoe findings, etc.

Owing to our loss at the Troy fire, we are compelled to conduct our business on a strictly cash system.

REMOVED.
